ASOS had £173m of net cash on its balance sheet in September 2016. However, it burned through £13m in FY 2016/17 and a further £117m in FY 2017/18, leaving it with just £43m of cash in September 2018.

ASOS has spent more on capex in the last two years (c.£400m) than in the previous 15 put together. But, only one-third is going on new warehouses. The proportion of total spending being capitalised has risen from 9% to 17% over the last 3 years.

BE11:20am

… so something's got to give. Having increased its borrowing facility to £150m, it has sufficient liquidity for the near-future. However, we now expect c.£90m of net debt in August 2020, when ASOS could find itself uncomfortably tight on liquidity ahead of peak trading. Unless cash flows improve, it may have to scale back its spending and growth ambitions.

Our earnings revision is driven by a significant increase in D&A charges.
Consensus D&A has yet to catch up with rising capex; over the last financial year, capex estimates were raised 37%, but consensus D&A two years out has fallen 7%. We now sit 26% below consensus earnings by FY2020/21. In our view, if ASOS is to continue to meet its medium-term EBIT margin target of 4%, EBITDA margins will need to increase to 8%+ in FY2021/22 (6.5% last year). Given the historical margin trajectory that feels demanding.

BE11:26am

It has undoubtedly been a dreadful year for Superdry and our Buy rating.
We believed the ongoing operational improvements were sufficient to
support high single-digit sales growth, but we had underappreciated the
extent of the product repositioning required. We again cut our EPS
forecasts by 8%/13%/10% in FY19E/FY20E/FY21E to reflect ongoing
weakness across the UK retail market, as well as our understanding that
the current strategy could take another c12 months to come to fruition.
This leaves us 12%/18% below FY19E/FY20E consensus. With this in mind,
while we believe there is upside to valuation once trading improves, we see potential for negative rather than positive catalysts on the horizon and downgrade to Hold with a GBp950 price target.

Tom Dalgleish online fashion retail would have a short half life non?
BE11:26am

Over-reliance on winter clothing: Superdry is now seven months into the
18-month product diversification and innovation programme it announced
at its September 2017 capital markets day, and we greatly
underappreciated the extent and impact of the product repositioning
taking place. While it has now begun to cut underperforming SKUs from
its winter ranges in favour of diversification into underpenetrated product
categories including womenswear and kidswear, it may take several
quarters to materially impact trading.

continue to weigh on lfl growth in the near term.

BE11:30am

The departure of Julian Dunkerton raises questions - At the time of the
Capital Markets Day last year, September 2017, Julian Dunkerton "was fully
committed to staying in the business and full belief in the future of the
business”. When Julian stepped aside as CEO to lead the development of the
brand and product this was a signal that he valued that role and the brand
much more than the role of CEO – it played to his strengths and made
strategic sense in our view.
The departure of Julian from the Group led us, at Liberum, to become more
cautious on the outlook. Rather simply, a brand is innately and inextricably
intertwined with its founders. James Holder was the head designer who with
Julian created SuperDry and Julian the chief commercial visionary who could
spot the gaps in the market place with a key sense of what would drive sales.
The combination is a proven one at identifying the future of the brand, ways to
drive growth with innovative new product, and ranges yet elevating and
keeping the continuity lines and mainstream product fresh and relevant.
What they were less good at was organising themselves and the business.
The current management team allowed for an improved structure and
processes in the business.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

We expect the European insurance sector to outperform the market in 2019. An increase in underlying customer demand with little change in supply should increase insurers’ pricing power, leading to growing earnings. Investors can be assured by a highly prudent solvency regime which keeps balance sheets strong and high-yielding dividends safe. Top Picks – Aviva, Beazley, Just Group, Legal and General . Outperforms – Ageas, Direct Line, Lancashire, Munich Re, Phoenix, RSA. UK life – limited Brexit risk creates buying opportunity. The subsector has underperformed due to the uncertainty caused by Brexit, but even in a No Deal scenario, solvency and growth are only dented. We see bulk annuities as the best structural growth opportunity in the sector — there is significant latent demand which is independent of economic growth and the prospect for large reserve releases due to slowing life expectancy. The yields are highly attractive and dividends are extremely safe.

BE11:34am

Wealth managers – underappreciated £1 trillion future prize. The share prices of the wealth managers do not reflect the scale of the potential defined benefit (DB) pension transfer opportunity. Management have understandably downplayed the opportunity due to worries that it be related to the 1988 – 1994 mis-selling scandal. The future prize is significant — almost £1tn of eligible assets are up for grabs.

BE11:35am

An asset manager’s earnings are a function of its AUM, which are at the mercy of financial market levels, with equity markets a major factor. We forecast that SLA’ s AUM will reduce by 9.4% CAGR between mid-2018 and end-2020. At its interim results, SLA said that dividend cover from continuing operations (excluding non-cash items and the Phoenix dividend) was just above 1x. Falls in financial markets have exacerbated the issue. At this rate, the current dividend policy will come under pressure, in our view. We calculate that outflows from GARS accelerated in November £2.7bn left the fund on a net basis over November, taking the cumulative net disinvestment to amount to £12.6bn over 2018 YTD, based on our analysis. We expect outflows to continue and adjust our 2018E net outflow forecast for GARS to £15bn (from £12bn). We maintain our net outflow forecasts of £7bn for 2019E and £5bn for 2020E. The insurance business was sold too cheaply, in our view We believe SLA sold its life insurance business at a 21% or £0.8bn discount to what it is worth, based on our calculation of its embedded value (£2.9bn versus our estimate of £3.7bn).

Ashtead’s Q2’19 results beat across the board and the analyst presentation confirmed the unchanged message from management that remains, in the simplest of terms, that the business remains well positioned to continue to outperform its markets and that these underlying markets are continuing to grow. We highlight here the key
takeaways from the analyst presentation but particularly flag; 1) Sunbelt underlying growth was ~22% (exhurricane impacts) and November saw ~22% growth y/y, 2) Rates have increased ~5% over the past two years
despite the fleet increasing ~40%, a reflection of a positive rate environment we see as being lost in monthly/quarterly variations, and, 3) Management does not see a slowdown in growth “any time soon”,
reflected in the size of the uplift in capex guidance. The shares have faded some of this morning’s initial gains but this, in our view, does not reflect any softening of the usual positive message from management or anything in the details of the Q2 numbers instead the pervasive nature of current top-down concerns. However, we continue to see the stock at the wrong level, trading on ~9.5x/~8.3x consensus FY19FY20 PE, even before today’s likely upgrades, with a FCF yield that is high-single-digits in a world where EPS is growing greater than 30% and would increase to mid-teens levels in a weaker backdrop.

BE11:48am

And Peel Hunt.

BE11:48am

Another warming result, with 6-month profits of £633m (+19%
at CER) vs PHe £601m. Group ROI was unchanged at 18%.
Sunbelt US (88% EBITA) saw 6-m rental revenues +19%, with
same store +16%. EBITDA drop through remains strong at 51%
(despite greenfield investment) to sustain margin above 51%.
Outlook remains upbeat, with underlying gross capex guidance
increased by £200m (now £1.4bn from £1.6bn). We increase our
April 2019 PBT from £1,075m (cons £1,048m) to £1,100m, to
give EPS of 174p from 169p (+3%). However, we have left
currency unchanged for now, but this could add a further 2%.
Shares have been weak on wider macro concerns and continue to
offer value on 8.6x April 2020 EPS given growth, quality and
positioning. We maintain our TP of 2,500p to reflect the
momentum and upgrades.

BE11:57am

WPP has issued a three-year turnaround plan to 2021, ahead of its Strategy Update later today, the first under the new CEO. Overall, the company has guided for 2021 net sales organic growth in line with peers (GSe: 1.5%) and headline operating margin (excluding associates) of at least 15% (GSe/consensus: 14.4%). WPP also reiterated 2018 organic growth guidance of -0.5% (GSe/consensus: -1.0%/-0.9%) while in 2019, organic is expected to be impacted by account losses, especially in 1H (GSe/consensus: -2.2%/-2.0%) and margins are likely to be impacted by investments in the business (GSe/consensus: 14.5%/14.7%). The company announced a £275 mn cost saving plan, of which half will be reinvested in the business to better align with its new priorities. WPP will incur cash restructuring costs of £300 mn over 2019-21. In terms of capital deployment, WPP will prioritise the dividend, maintaining it at 60p/share over 2019-21 and prioritise it over buybacks.
While limited in terms of details, we view the release as a positive for the stock and look for further granularity in the presentations this afternoon on the main drivers of the organic growth target, a bridge to the 2021 margin target, potential changes to management incentives, further portfolio simplification as well as uses of cash.

cracklenpop @upaswellasdown 'that sort of thing' is one reason why readers still buy - and trust - newspapers.

As previously announced, the Board of WPP has decided to develop Kantar with a potential strategic or financial partner, with WPP retaining a significant minority interest and strategic links with Kantar. Proposals will be evaluated on their financial and strategic benefits and if a transaction is agreed it is likely to be announced in the second quarter of 2019. Preparations are well underway and we have received numerous unsolicited expressions of interest.
